currentDoc:
Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa.

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies a

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an ext

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition.

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition.

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition. 

Extreme is a word that doesn't have a concrete definition. What's extreme for a certain portion of people is normal for others. Hence why there is no lin

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition. 

Extreme is a word that doesn't have a concrete definition. What's extreme for a certain portion of people is normal for others. Hence why there is no line that needs to be drawn.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. Extreme is a word that doesn't have a concrete definition. What's extreme for a certain portion of people is normal for others. Hence why there is no line that needs to be drawn.

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition. 

Extreme is a word that doesn't have a concrete definition. What's extreme for a certain portion of people is normal for others. Hence why there is no line that needs to be drawn.

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition. 

Extreme is a word that doesn't have a concrete definition. What's extreme for a certain portion of people is normal for others. Hence why there is no line that needs to be drawn.

The only time I think a line should be drawn is as a parent. If you as a parent don't feel comfortable with your child playing football for exam

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition. 

Extreme is a word that doesn't have a concrete definition. What's extreme for a certain portion of people is normal for others. Hence why there is no line that needs to be drawn.

The only time I think a line should be drawn is as a parent. If you as a parent don't feel comfortable with your child playing football for example due to fears of concussions and broken

At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition. 

Extreme is a word that doesn't have a concrete definition. What's extreme for a certain portion of people is normal for others. Hence why there is no line that needs to be drawn.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition. 

Extreme is a word that doesn't have a concrete definition. What's extreme for a certain portion of people is normal for others. Hence why there is no line that needs to be drawn.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition. 

Extreme is a word that doesn't have a concrete definition. What's extreme for a certain portion of people is normal for others. Hence why there is no line that needs to be drawn.

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition. 

Extreme is a word that doesn't have a concrete definition. What's extreme for a certain portion of people is normal for others. Hence why there is no line that needs to be drawn.

The only time I think a line should be drawn is as a parent. If you as a parent don't feel comfortable with your child playing football for example due to fears of concussions and broken bones, that is entirely your right. Your priority as a parent is to keep your child safe

But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition. 

Extreme is a word that doesn't have a concrete definition. What's extreme for a certain portion of people is normal for others. Hence why there is no line that needs to be drawn.

The only time I think a line should be drawn is as a parent. If you as a parent don't feel comfortable with your child playing football for example due to fears of concussions and broken bones, that is entirely your right. Your priority as a parent is to keep your child safe. You get to draw that

At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition. 

Extreme is a word that doesn't have a concrete definition. What's extreme for a certain portion of people is normal for others. Hence why there is no line that needs to be drawn.

The only time I think a line should be drawn is as a parent. If you as a parent don't feel comfortable with your child playing football for example due to fears of concussions and broken bones, that is entirely your right. Your priority as a parent is to keep your child safe. You get to draw that line.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition. 

Extreme is a word that doesn't have a concrete definition. What's extreme for a certain portion of people is normal for others. Hence why there is no line that needs to be drawn.

The only time I think a line should be drawn is as a parent. If you as a parent don't feel comfortable with your child playing football for example due to fears of concussions and broken bones, that is entirely your right. Your priority as a parent is to keep your child safe. You get to draw that line. 

When it comes to extreme sports, th

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition. 

Extreme is a word that doesn't have a concrete definition. What's extreme for a certain portion of people is normal for others. Hence why there is no line that needs to be drawn.

The only time I think a line should be drawn is as a parent. If you as a parent don't feel comfortable with your child playing football for example due to fears of concussions and broken bones, that is entirely your right. Your priority as a parent is to keep your child safe. You get to draw that line. 

When it comes to extreme sports, there's no such thing a

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, one decides where the line may be drawn based off of their own personality and thoughts. I can't tell you what is too extreme or too dangerous when it comes to sports and vice versa. 

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition. 

Extreme is a word that doesn't have a concrete definition. What's extreme for a certain portion of people is normal for others. Hence why there is no line that needs to be drawn.

The only time I think a line should be drawn is as a parent. If you as a parent don't feel comfortable with your child playing football for example due to fears of concussions and broken bones, that is entirely your right. Your priority as a parent is to keep your child safe. You get to draw that line. 

When it comes to extreme sports, there's no such thing as something that is too extreme for the g

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition. 

Extreme is a word that doesn't have a concrete definition. What's extreme for a certain portion of people is normal for others. Hence why there is no line that needs to be drawn.

The only time I think a line should be drawn is as a parent. If you as a parent don't feel comfortable with your child playing football for example due to fears of concussions and broken bones, that is entirely your right. Your priority as a parent is to keep your child safe. You get to draw that line. 

When it comes to extreme sports, there's no such thing as something that is too extreme for the general population

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition. 

Extreme is a word that doesn't have a concrete definition. What's extreme for a certain portion of people is normal for others. Hence why there is no line that needs to be drawn.

The only time I think a line should be drawn is as a parent. If you as a parent don't feel comfortable with your child playing football for example due to fears of concussions and broken bones, that is entirely your right. Your priority as a parent is to keep your child safe. You get to draw that line. 

When it comes to extreme sports, there's no such thing as something that is too extreme for the general population. This country is gr

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition. 

Extreme is a word that doesn't have a concrete definition. What's extreme for a certain portion of people is normal for others. Hence why there is no line that needs to be drawn.

The only time I think a line should be drawn is as a parent. If you as a parent don't feel comfortable with your child playing football for example due to fears of concussions and broken bones, that is entirely your right. Your priority as a parent is to keep your child safe. You get to draw that line. 

When it comes to extreme sports, there's no such thing as something that is too extreme for the general population. This world is great because we get to make our own decisions a

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

I am afraid of getting hurt and therefore don't really put myself in situations for that to happen. You won't catch me going extreme mountain climbing, snowboarding, skiing or anything like that. 

I am a boots on the ground person. I'm not a risk taker and think that people who are adrenaline junkies and seek risks are nuts. But I'm not going to tell them that they can't jump out of a plane and they can't ski down an extremely steep mountain/slope. At the end of the day, we all make choices and decisions in our life and we have the freedom to live the way that we want to. I don't have the right to define what danger is for other people.

I don't think any sport is too dangerous to be called a sport. Boxing and MMA are two of the most popular sports in the world and they feature blood and knockouts all the time. Those fighters know what they are signing up for and most of them love the competition. 

Extreme is a word that doesn't have a concrete definition. What's extreme for a certain portion of people is normal for others. Hence why there is no line that needs to be drawn.

The only time I think a line should be drawn is as a parent. If you as a parent don't feel comfortable with your child playing football for example due to fears of concussions and broken bones, that is entirely your right. Your priority as a parent is to keep your child safe. You get to draw that line. 

When it comes to extreme sports, there's no such thing as something that is too extreme for the general population. This world is great because we get to make our own decisions and live with the con

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?
